filteredArticles.headline: University of California will end use of SAT, ACT in admissions entirely by fall 2025
filteredArticles.abstract: Brian Taylor, managing director of New York City-based college admissions consulting firm Ivy Coach, believes the decision will influence other universities, and said it is likely that highly selective universities, such as Ivy League institutions, will be test-optional in the future.
filteredArticles.infobox:
RELATED:

Here’s how Ivy League universities are changing testing requirements for the Class of 2025

Penn ranked eighth best U.S. university by Quacquarelli Symonds

filteredArticles.headline: Here’s how Ivy League universities are changing testing requirements for the Class of 2025
filteredArticles.abstract: College Board and ACT testing agencies canceled and postponed multiple test dates in response to the pandemic, prompting many universities to change standardized test requirements for future applicants.
filteredArticles.infobox:

filteredArticles.headline: Penn Admissions and Kite and Key unveil first live, virtual tour in the Ivy League
filteredArticles.abstract: Each tour is capped at 50 students, and led by two Kite and Key tour guides and up to four admissions officers to ensure all questions asked through the Zoom platform’s chat feature are answered.

filteredArticles.headline: While colleges struggle to fill Class of 2024, Penn has not yet increased waitlist admissions
filteredArticles.abstract: Admissions experts say schools are anxious about international students possibly not being able to arrive on campus for the fall semester, and about domestic students who may choose to take a gap year instead of enrolling amid the coronavirus.

filteredArticles.headline: Penn reminds incoming international students of gap year option as coronavirus spreads
filteredArticles.abstract: Because U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services suspended routine visa services at all embassies and consulates due to COVID-19, it is unclear if new international students will be able to secure visas in time for the fall semester.

filteredArticles.headline: Penn admits 8.07% of applicants to the Class of 2024, a slight uptick from last year
filteredArticles.abstract: Penn admitted 3,404 out of 42,205 applicants for the Class of 2024. At 8.07%, this year's acceptance rate is slightly higher than last year's 7.44%.

dominantMedia.content: Members from the Class of 2024 come from all 50 states and 98 different countries.

filteredArticles.headline: Penn Admissions cancels Quaker Days events for admitted students due to coronavirus fears
filteredArticles.abstract: This year's Quaker Days events, which were planned for April 6 and April 15, and the Multicultural Scholars Preview program on April 14, have been canceled, Dean of Admissions Eric Furda wrote in a press release.
filteredArticles.infobox:
RELATED:

dominantMedia.title: Quaker Days Canceled Coronavirus.jpg
dominantMedia.content: Quaker Days annually brings newly-admitted students to Penn to experience the campus before making their final college decisions.

filteredArticles.headline: Penn's RD applications drop by nearly 3,000 for the Class of 2024, a year after record high
filteredArticles.abstract: Penn received 42,191 applications for the Class of 2024, nearly 3,000 less than last year's applicant pool, breaking nearly a decade of steady growth.
filteredArticles.infobox:

filteredArticles.headline: Johns Hopkins University says campus diversity increased after ending legacy admissions
filteredArticles.abstract: Legacy students comprised only 5% of Johns Hopkins University's incoming freshman class in 2014, down from 12.5% in 2009.

dominantMedia.title: Johns Hopkins.jpg
dominantMedia.content: Johns Hopkins completely phased out preferential legacy admissions in 2014. (Photo from Pixabay)

filteredArticles.headline: Here's how Penn's ED stats for the Class of 2024 compare to the other Ivies
filteredArticles.abstract: Penn saw a 9% decline in number of ED applicants from last year’s 7,109 applicants. Harvard and Yale also experienced a decline in early action applicants from last year.

filteredArticles.headline: Penn's early decision acceptance rate increases to 19.7% for Class of 2024
filteredArticles.abstract: The 1,269 students offered admission account for approximately 53% of the expected enrolling class. This year, Penn received 6,453 early decision applications, a 9% decline from last year’s 7,109 applicants.
filteredArticles.infobox:

dominantMedia.title: 2019 ED Acceptances
dominantMedia.content: Last year, Penn recorded its lowest ED acceptance rate, admitting just 18% of the applicant pool to the Class of 2023.

filteredArticles.headline: Penn early decision applications drop 14% from last year
filteredArticles.abstract: For the 2019 early decision deadline, Penn received 6,088 applications, while 2018 saw 7,109 applications.

dominantMedia.title: ED Statistics Class of 2024
dominantMedia.content: Penn Admissions also changed the essay portion of the 2019-2020 application.

filteredArticles.headline: Wharton expands MBA early admission program to undergrads from any university
filteredArticles.abstract: The program, called Wharton MBA Advance Access, now allows student in their final year from any university to be accepted early to the full-time MBA program after working for two to four years after graduation.
filteredArticles.infobox:
RELATED:

Wharton raises cost of MBA degree as peer institutions halt tuition increase

Penn Engineering sub-matriculants must now complete undergraduate degree in 4 years

dominantMedia.title: Wharton Admissions
dominantMedia.content: The MBA Admissions Committee assesses applications based on academic rigor, standardized test scores (GMAT or GRE), work experience, letters of recommendation, among other considerations.

filteredArticles.headline: Dean Furda's Eagles tirade featured on Stephen Colbert's late-night show
filteredArticles.abstract: “Plot twist: turns out that man is Eric Furda, the University of Pennsylvania’s dean of admissions,” Colbert said to horrified laughter from the audience.
filteredArticles.infobox:

filteredArticles.headline: Nearly half of white Harvard students are athletes or children of alumni or donors
filteredArticles.abstract: The study found that 43% of white students admitted to Harvard between 2009 and 2014 were legacy, children of faculty and donors, or athletes.
filteredArticles.infobox:

dominantMedia.title: harvard campus
dominantMedia.content: Researchers from Duke University, University of Georgia, and University of Oklahoma, found that 43% of Harvard's white admits had one of these admissions advantages. (Joseph Williams | CC BY 2.0)

filteredArticles.headline: Class of 2023 yield rate jumps to 70% —  Penn’s highest in 10 years
filteredArticles.abstract: This year, 70% of 3,345 admitted students accepted their offers, the highest yield rate since the 2009-2010 academic year.

dominantMedia.title: Fall College Hall Green.jpg
dominantMedia.content: It has not yet been announced when Penn's campus will reopen.

filteredArticles.headline: Evidence of college admissions scam uncovered by FBI years before Jerome Allen scandal
filteredArticles.abstract: Authorities discovered the college consultant at the center of the national scandal in 2016 while investigating Philip Esformes, the parent who bribed a former coach to help ensure his son's admission to Penn, the Los Angeles Times reported.

filteredArticles.headline: Penn's transfer acceptance rate drops to record-low 5.9%
filteredArticles.abstract: The acceptance rate of 5.9% constitutes a marked decrease from recent years with an acceptance rate of 7.6% last year and 8.1% in 2017.

filteredArticles.headline: A look at the Penn admissions visitor center a month since its move to Claudia Cohen Hall
filteredArticles.abstract: The admissions center moved to the basement of Claudia Cohen Hall in late May after nine months of construction. The new center offers a bigger space and its design reflects Penn Admissions' recent re-branding.
